data.title: Literature by Women for All, Because Our Stories Matter

data.text:
One day recently, I came across an article in Forbes that caught my attention. It was discussing the inequality on Portuguese bookshelves. I’m not referring to their material, although I appreciate good old cherry wood with cuts from past centuries.

No objections there.

But what I mean is their content, what they carry in each compartment. In this case, the inequality regarding the lack of female voices is evident. It’s a clear objection that starts with Portuguese school curricula reflecting precisely that. I don’t need to think too much to realize that men have always shaped my Portuguese language and literature education.

In school, except for the wonder of being introduced to Sophia de Mello Breyner when I was very young, she was later cast aside. It’s as if the childhood world is insignificant, and everything considered more serious and, therefore, of greater relevance, belongs to the adult world, which means men’s world.
